segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Impersonate a client after authentication security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Impersonate a client after authentication security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Impersonate a client after authentication security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Impersonate a client after authentication security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which programs are allowed to impersonate a user or another specified account and act on behalf of the user.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which programs are allowed to impersonate a user or another specified account and act on behalf of the user.

segment.source: If this user right is required for this type of impersonation, an unauthorized user cannot cause a client to connect (for example, by remote procedure call (RPC) or named pipes) to a service that they have created to impersonate that client.
segment.target: If this user right is required for this type of impersonation, an unauthorized user cannot cause a client to connect (for example, by remote procedure call (RPC) or named pipes) to a service that they have created to impersonate that client.

segment.source: (Such an action could elevate the unauthorized user's permissions to administrative or system levels.)
segment.target: (Such an action could elevate the unauthorized user's permissions to administrative or system levels.)

segment.source: Impersonation is the ability of a thread to run in a security context that is different from the context of the process that owns the thread.
segment.target: Impersonation is the ability of a thread to run in a security context that is different from the context of the process that owns the thread.

segment.source: Impersonation is designed to meet the security requirements of client/server applications.
segment.target: Impersonation is designed to meet the security requirements of client/server applications.

segment.source: When running in a client's security context, a service "is" the client, to some degree.
segment.target: When running in a client's security context, a service "is" the client, to some degree.

segment.source: One of the service's threads uses an access token representing the client's credentials to obtain access to the objects to which the client has access.
segment.target: One of the service's threads uses an access token representing the client's credentials to obtain access to the objects to which the client has access.

segment.source: The primary reason for impersonation is to cause access checks to be performed against the client's identity.
segment.target: The primary reason for impersonation is to cause access checks to be performed against the client's identity.

segment.source: Using the client's identity for access checks can cause access to be either restricted or expanded, depending on what the client has permission to do.
segment.target: Using the client's identity for access checks can cause access to be either restricted or expanded, depending on what the client has permission to do.

segment.source: Services that are started by the Service Control Manager have the built-in Service group added by default to their access tokens.
segment.target: Services that are started by the Service Control Manager have the built-in Service group added by default to their access tokens.

segment.source: COM servers that are started by the COM infrastructure and configured to run under a specific account also have the Service group added to their access tokens.
segment.target: COM servers that are started by the COM infrastructure and configured to run under a specific account also have the Service group added to their access tokens.

segment.source: As a result, these processes are assigned this user right when they are started.
segment.target: As a result, these processes are assigned this user right when they are started.

segment.source: A user can impersonate an access token if any of the following conditions exist:
segment.target: A user can impersonate an access token if any of the following conditions exist:

segment.source: The access token that is being impersonated is for this user.
segment.target: The access token that is being impersonated is for this user.

segment.source: The user in this session logged on to the network with explicit credentials to create the access token.
segment.target: The user in this session logged on to the network with explicit credentials to create the access token.

segment.source: The requested level is less than Impersonate, such as Anonymous or Identify.
segment.target: The requested level is less than Impersonate, such as Anonymous or Identify.

segment.source: Because of these factors, users do not usually need to have this user right assigned.
segment.target: Because of these factors, users do not usually need to have this user right assigned.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: By default, this setting is Administrators, Local Service, Network Service, and Service on domain controllers and stand-alone servers.
segment.target: By default, this setting is Administrators, Local Service, Network Service, and Service on domain controllers and stand-alone servers.

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.
segment.target: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: An attacker with the Impersonate a client after authentication user right could create a service, mislead a client into connecting to the service, and then impersonate that computer to elevate the attacker's level of access to that of the device.
segment.target: An attacker with the Impersonate a client after authentication user right could create a service, mislead a client into connecting to the service, and then impersonate that computer to elevate the attacker's level of access to that of the device.

segment.source: On member servers, ensure that only the Administrators and Service groups (Local Service, Network Service, and Service) have the Impersonate a client after authentication user right assigned to them.
segment.target: On member servers, ensure that only the Administrators and Service groups (Local Service, Network Service, and Service) have the Impersonate a client after authentication user right assigned to them.

segment.source: In most cases, this configuration has no impact.
segment.target: In most cases, this configuration has no impact.

segment.source: If you have installed optional components such as ASP.NET or IIS, you may need to assign the Impersonate a client after authentication user right to additional accounts that are required by those components, such as IUSRComputerName, IISWPG, ASP.NET, or IWAMComputerName.
segment.target: If you have installed optional components such as ASP.NET or IIS, you may need to assign the Impersonate a client after authentication user right to additional accounts that are required by those components, such as IUSRComputerName, IISWPG, ASP.NET, or IWAMComputerName.
